journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Lubrication of 2D soft elastohydrodynamic contacts: Extension of the amplitude reduction theory

article-meta.aff: 2LaMCoS, INSA-Lyon, CNRS, Université de Lyon, UMR 5259, Villeurbanne, France

author-notes.corresp: F Mora, Michelin Technology Center, Rue Bleue, 63118 Cébazat, France. Email: florian.mora@insa-lyon.fr

permissions.copyright-statement: © Manufacture Française des Pneumatiques Michelin, France 2012

abstract.p: Surface roughness plays an important role in the performance of soft elastohydrodynamically lubricated contacts. When a soft and smooth body is in contact with a very rigid and rough one, the roughness creates pressure fluctuations, resulting in the deformation of the soft body. As the contact pressure is low, the fluid can be considered isoviscous and incompressible. An extension of the amplitude reduction theory from the piezoviscous to isoviscous elastic regime is performed under pure rolling conditions. It shows that a single master curve can be obtained by providing an analytic formula, but the power on the load parameter is different in the piezoviscous and isoviscous elastic zones.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lubrication of soft contacts plays an important role in technology. This type of lubrication behaviour is found in seals and vehicle tyres. The surface roughness has a significant influence on performances such as wear, load-carrying capacity and friction. So, it is very important to understand the contact behaviour as a function of the roughness parameters.

In these contacts, the pressure is low, and thus, the fluid viscosity η can be taken as a constant. The same is true for the fluid density ρ. Deformation occurs at these low pressures as the elastic modulus of the contacting solids is low. Hence, large elastic deformations can occur in these contacts, both on a macroscale (contact dimension) and on a microscale (roughness dimension). As such, the behaviour is similar to the behaviour of highly loaded elastohydrodynamically lubricated (EHL) contacts. To distinguish the two regimes, the latter is ‘coined’ piezoviscous elastic (PE), whereas the former is named isoviscous elastic (IE). To describe the two regimes and to generate the dimensionless numbers, the two-dimensional (2D) Moes parameters are introduced. These parameters M and L can be related to the Hamrock Dowson parameters: M = W/U3/4, L = GU1/4. Using these parameters, the PE regime can be roughly defined as M > 10, L > 2.5 and the IE regime M > 10, L = 0.

Rough contacts in oil seals have been studied both theoretically1–6 and experimentally.7,8 For vehicle tyres, the roughness impact on wet tyre friction was studied theoretically9,10 and experimentally.10–12 These papers do not describe deterministic transient roughness but use techniques like Patir and Cheng's flow factors or a roughness modification with a dry contact solver. Hadinata and Stephens13 have studied the effect of shaft asperities on the load-carrying capacity of oil seals. The aim of this study is to correctly model the roughness under lubrication conditions.

The problem of the lubrication of soft (rough) contacts has been addressed by Hooke and Li14 with an isoviscous fluid. Shinkarenko et al.15 studied the soft EHL contact using a numerical model of a textured rigid surface on a soft elastic smooth one. For an isoviscous fluid, the surface texturing increases the load-carrying capacity. Scaraggi et al.16 experimentally studied soft contacts and reports on the existence of micro-EHL.

The roughness deformation in the PE regime has been extensively studied using measured roughness profiles17 and studying the behaviour of wavy surfaces. The second approach is adopted in this study. The amplitude reduction literature18–20 shows that a unique master curve is obtained when plotting the relative deformed amplitude Ad/Ai as a function of a dimensionless waviness parameter ∇=(λ/a)(M2/L6), where λ is the waviness wavelength and a the contact radius.

This parameter has been interpreted as the ratio of the waviness wavelength to the inlet boundary layer.18 It is clear that this approach is interesting, as it predicts the waviness behaviour analytically. Using Fourier decomposition, the behaviour of a ‘real’ rough surface can be analysed as a function of the operating conditions. The predictions of the amplitude reduction theory (ART) under pure rolling conditions have recently been verified experimentally by Sperka et al.21

It is obvious that a straightforward use of the ∇ parameter in the IE regime is impossible as ∇ = ∞ for L = 0. Hence, an extension of the current ART is required for the IE regime under a pure rolling condition. In particular, a special ∇ parameter has to be devised. However, Hooke22 has studied the amplitude reduction in line contact for the IE regime, and using a similar parameter obtains a single curve but with a large scatter.

sec.title: Theory
sec.p: The dimensionless Reynolds equation for the transient point contact problem reads (1)∂∂X(ε∂P∂X)+∂∂Y(ε∂P∂Y)-∂(ρ¯H)∂X-∂(ρ¯H)∂T=0 The boundary conditions are P(Xa, Y, T) = P(Xb, Y, T) = P(X, Ya, T) = P(X, Yb, T) = 0, ∀T where Xa, Xb, Ya and Yb denote the boundaries of the domain. Furthermore, the cavitation condition P(X, Y, T) ≥ 0, ∀X, Y, T must be satisfied. ϵ and λ¯ are defined according to ε=ρ¯H3η¯λ¯ λ¯=12η0u¯Rx 2a3ph The density ρ and the viscosity η are assumed constant because of the IE regime, hence: ρ¯=η¯=1.

The film thickness equation is made dimensionless using the same Hertzian parameters and accounting for a moving surface waviness ℛ reads (2) where ℛ(X, Y, T) denotes the undeformed geometry of the surface waviness at dimensionless time T and H0(T) an integration constant (3) The deformation term is calculated using the multi-level multi-integration technique on the Boussinesq equation. As we study pure rolling conditions, we neglect the transverse deformation, even though the contact is soft. So, only the normal deformation will be taken into account.

For simplicity, the waviness is isotropic (i.e. λx = λy). The waviness equation is damped using an exponential, to start from a smooth contact stationary solution and to add the roughness in a physically correct manner. This avoids unphysical start-up effects. The deformed amplitude was ‘measured’ when a periodic response of film thickness as a function of time was reached. The Ai value is chosen approximately equal to 0.1 Hc to remain in the linear range. A non-linear extension of the theory is described by Biboulet et al.23,24

At all times, the force balance condition is imposed, i.e. the integral over the pressure must balance the externally applied contact load. This condition determines the value of the integration constant H0(T) in equation (2). Expressed as dimensionless variables, the equation reads (4)∫∫ΩP(X,Y,T) dX dY-2π3=0, ∀T In physical terms, this equation means that the acceleration forces of the contacting bodies are neglected.
All these equations are discretised to second-order precision and solved using multi-level techniques, as described in Venner and Lubrecht.25

The deformed amplitude of the waviness is defined as a function of the operating conditions through the following relation (5)Ad=maxTH(0,0,T)-minTH(0,0,T)2 The time T is chosen large enough to avoid start-up effects.

The soft EHL contact can be interpreted as a rigid rough surface in contact with a smooth and soft one. In consequence, only the smooth and soft elastic body will deform, not the roughness. This is different from all previous amplitude reduction studies. In fact, this view is more representative of real problems presented in the `Introduction'.

For example, in a tyre/road contact, the rigid rough surface is the road and the smooth and soft one is the rubber. In the same manner, for the oil seal contact, the rigid rough surface is the shaft and the second the oil seal. So, the results can be interpreted as the influence of the roughness of the rigid bodies on the deformation of the elastic smooth one.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The results will be described using the ratio Ad/Ai which is the variation of the central gap height over the amplitude of the initial roughness. As we are in the linear range, it is possible to study this ratio directly instead of varying Ai.

Figure 1(a) shows the centre-line geometry and pressure with amplified fluctuations and (b) shows the same results in 3D for M = 1000 and λ/a = 0.5. Figure 1.
(a) Centre-line fluctuations of film thickness and pressure and (b) 3D film thickness and pressure distribution.

As shown in Figure 2, the rigid roughness creates pressure variations, resulting in a deformation of the elastic body. For pure rolling conditions, the deformation has the same phase as the roughness and has, in this example, half as the roughness amplitude: Ad/Ai = 0.5. Figure 2.
2D contact geometry for Ad/Ai = 0.5.

The most straightforward approach to modify the ∇ parameter for the IE regime is to remove the L from the denominator (6)∇=(λ/a)M2 Figure 3 shows the amplitude reduction Ad/Ai as a function of the modified waviness parameter ∇. Figure 3.
Ad/Ai as a function of ∇ in the IE regime. IE: isoelastic.

Pure rolling numerical calculations varying M and λ show that indeed a single master curve is obtained with this parameter. The load parameter M was varied from 500 to 2000 and the dimensionless roughness wavelength λ from 0.15 to 3.
The results show that a single curve is obtained with some scatter around Ad/Ai = 0.5. This scatter is similar to the one obtained by Hooke22 for the isoviscous line contact problem.

A more detailed analysis of this scatter is shown in Figure 4. It can be deduced that the proposed relation between ∇ and M can be improved. This scatter is not random, but the high M values lie consistently above the low M values. As such, it is obvious that this problem comes from the power ratio between λ and M. Figure 4.
Ad/Ai as a function of ∇ for M = 500, bottom, and M = 2000, top.

To reduce this scatter, the power of M was modified. A best fit was found for a 1/3 power (7)∇¯=(λ/a)M3 This parameter differs significantly from the one obtained by Hooke22 for the line contact problem.

A two-parameter least-squares fit on the data is found, but is different from the EHL relations (8)AdAi=11+0.0018∇¯7/2 Figure 5 shows that a single curve with much less scatter was obtained and that equation (8) fits the data points relatively well. Figure 5.
Ad/Ai as a function of ∇¯, continuous curve: equation (8).

That the power of M in the PE and IE regimes differs does hardly surprise when one remembers the film thickness dependence on M (IE: Hie M=1.96M-1/9 and PE: Hpe M=1.25M-1/12L3/4), see Moes.26 So, it seems difficult to create a simple relation, enabling the transition between the PE and the IE regimes.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the PE regime, it was straightforward to assume that the waviness amplitude was constant in the ‘high pressure zone’ as the Poiseuille flow is zero in this zone. For the IE regime, it is more complicated, because of the isoviscosity, the pressure variations decrease towards the exit. So, the Poiseuille term of the Reynolds equation is non-zero, creating waviness amplitude changes.

These fluctuations have been studied over the contact zone. In all cases, Ad increases as a function of X. In X-direction, the variations are less than 10% from the central value for sufficiently large waviness values (λ/a > 1). It is possible to model this variation in the X-direction27 but it is much more complicated in the Y-direction.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study analyses the extension of the amplitude reduction of waviness in EHL point contacts for the IE regime. The study suggests that a single master curve exists, describing the amplitude reduction under pure rolling conditions. The amplitude reduction is maximum for long wavelengths or low elastic moduli, i.e. Ad/Ai(∇ = ∞) = 0, and is minimum for short wavelengths or high elastic moduli, i.e. Ad/Ai(∇ = 0) = 1.
The ∇¯ parameter has enabled a single master curve using all parameters in the contact (a, λ and M).

Unfortunately, the dependence of ∇ on M differs in the IE regime; 1/3 compared to the 1/2 for the PE regime. Finally, due to the IE regime behaviour, it is not possible to directly extend contact centre results over the entire contact zone.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
